awd_abstract_narration:
Many studies of objects in the sky that vary in brightness look only at periodic variation, with a regular and repeating change with time.  However, most variable astronomical sources are aperiodic, showing erratic and irregular changes.  They remain poorly studied in comparison to periodic sources, even though they can play a key role in our understanding of complex dynamic physical environments, from stars, to gas and dust flows, to galaxies.  This work studies aperiodic variability using the data from two NSF-supported projects, the Catalina Real-time Transient Survey (CRTS), and the newly begun Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF).  This is the first large-scale systematic study of these phenomena, and it will be the definitive study, well into the next decade.  It is an excellent case study for data-intensive science, applying state-of-the-art machine learning techniques to real data.  It will expose students to cutting-edge data science, and its products will contribute to projects that will train the next generation in how to handle big astronomical data.

Even though the majority of variable sources are aperiodic, they are poorly understood, and for well-known examples like quasars and young stellar objects many fundamental questions remain about the physical mechanisms behind their optical variability.  New sky surveys are enabling systematic studies of variability and discovering many new phenomena, including sub-parsec separated quasar binaries, multi-year long flares attributable to microlensing of explosive activity in the accretion disk, and changing-state sources indicative of variable accretion rates.  These extreme behaviors should be easily discoverable with modern robust statistical methods.  This work will create generative data-derived models with novel non-parametric discriminating features from CRTS data, and use the models to predict the future behavior of aperiodic sources, which can then be monitored in real-time using ZTF and other synoptic facilities.  Prior work focused on robust statistical characterization and identifying extreme variable classes.  This will be extended to more general aperiodic sources and more sophisticated non-parametric generative models.  The unprecedented sky coverage of ZTF joins with the unequalled archival coverage of CRTS to make this the definitive study.  In keeping with the CRTS Open Data and ZTF alert policies, all transitioning objects identified will be released to the community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The majority of variable astrophysical sources are not periodic and the best known class of aperiodic objects is active galactic nuclei (AGNs). However, a lack of suitable statistical tools has meant that their optical variability is poorly studied and fundamental questions remain about the physical mechanisms behind it. This project aims to address this by developing advanced machine learning techniques to characterize the temporal behavior seen in AGNs in current large sky surveys, such as the Catalina Real-time Transient Survey and the Zwicky Transient Facility.

Changing-look quasars are a rare group where strong photometric variability is accompanied by strong spectroscopic variability: the sources give the appearance of turning on or turning off. This is believed to be due to changing rates of accretion onto the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy. Using particular statistics tuned to the patterns of behavior seen, this project has more than doubled the number of known changing-look quasars and the first high redshift examples have been found.

Deep neural networks automatically learn how to best characterize input data and so should provide the best descriptor of any variability seen. The application of a recurrent neural network autoencoder model to AGN time series has been shown to outperform the standard statistical model for AGN variability, both in terms of accuracy and predictability. It has also identified a novel relationship: AGN variability is temporally asymmetric, i.e., the prediction accuracy for a time-reversed light is less than for the original light curve. The magnitude of the asymmetry decreases with increasing luminosity and/or black hole mass.

The accretion disks of AGN are a promising location for stellar mass black hole-black hole mergers, the gravitational wave signals of which are detected by LIGO. However, as this is a rich gas environment rather than empty space, it is possible that the black hole merger could produce a counterpart electromagnetic flare. This is caused by the motion of the merged black hole through the accretion disk. A search for a counterpart to LIGO detected events from the first half of the LIGO O3 run was conducted and a candidate source identified. This is associated with the gravitational wave event GW190521g, a high mass merger with high spin which is consistent with a merger in an AGN accretion disk.

This work has formed the basis of one graduate thesis project, one senior thesis project and three summer undergraduate research projects. The data sets compiled have also been used in the NSF-funded La Serena Data Science School for 3-day student projects in the application of data science techniques to time series analysis.
